DataElement.preferredName: Minor Component Malignant Neoplasm Intratumoral Heterogeneity Mitotic Count Score Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric range and score that represents the mitoses counted microscopically per high power field of a minor component with intratumoral morphologic heterogeneity characteristics.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Minor Element Malignant Neoplasm Intratumoral Heterogeneity Mitotic Count
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Lesser or smaller in amount, extent, or size._An artifact that is one of the individual parts of which a composite entity is made up; especially a part that can be separated from or attached to a system._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004 _Within a tumor._The quality or state of consisting of elements that are not of the same kind or nature._The number of mitoses identified under the microscope in tumors.  It is one of the parameters that determine the grade of malignant tumors.  The method of counting varies, according to the specific tumor examined.  Usually the mitotic count is determined based on the number of mitoses per high power field (40X) or 10 high power fields.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Lesser or smaller in amount, extent, or size.:An artifact that is one of the individual parts of which a composite entity is made up; especially a part that can be separated from or attached to a system.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: Lesser or smaller in amount, extent, or size.
An artifact that is one of the individual parts of which a composite entity is made up; especially a part that can be separated from or attached to a system.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: Within a tumor.:The quality or state of consisting of elements that are not of the same kind or nature.:The number of mitoses identified under the microscope in tumors. It is one of the parameters that determine the grade of malignant tumors. The method of counting varies, according to the specific tumor examined. Usually the mitotic count is determined based on the number of mitoses per high power field (40X) or 10 high power fields.

Concepts.definition: The quality or state of consisting of elements that are not of the same kind or nature.

The number of mitoses identified under the microscope in tumors.  It is one of the parameters that determine the grade of malignant tumors.  The method of counting varies, according to the specific tumor examined.  Usually the mitotic count is determined based on the number of mitoses per high power field (40X) or 10 high power fields.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Released per approval by M.Sheth. mc 12/14/11

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The number of mitoses identified under the microscope in tumors. It is one of the parameters that determine the grade of malignant tumors. The method of counting varies, according to the specific tumor examined.  Usually the mitotic count is determined based on the number of mitoses per high power field (40X) or 10 high power fields.
